subs.text: So I have spent some time sitting where you are.
A long time ago! :smile:
i come from tech so that's most of what i'll talk about
we need journalists who are comfortable with tech
subs.title: Notes for CUNY talk

subs.text: and fearless
and visionaries

body.text: Every so often journalism has to digest a technology, and usually they blow it

subs.text: confuse simple things as hard things and vice versa.
the initial scandal for facebook, cambridge analytica, was fairly random
the facebook features they were using had been around since 2012
everyone had access to them, and they were covered in journalism in glowing terms
every facebook dev had access. i was such a person. users knew about this. if it was news for journos you have to wonder if they were users.
reporting on this stuff, up till 2016 when they discovered these features could be used for bad stuff, they were hyping it. look what the boy wonder did! (typical uninformed journalism enthusiasm)
having been in this world for 2 decades at that point, we understood quite well where this can go wrong.
they didn't listen. we weren't important. ooops there goes the democracy. ;-)
they didn't look at the potential downside, and it hit them all at once
they made a big stink about something that wasn't even news

body.text: journalism tends to be black and white on tech

subs.text: either it's a gift from god or the spawn of satan
facebook is always evolving, it's not evil and it is evil
it's so many things. it's got almost 3 billion users
not all those people are trying to bring down the world order
i'm on a lot of groups for things i love, and i wouldn't want to live without facebook
yet journalism presents a very negative view of it
it's naive, wrong, costly

body.text: the hillary's emails story was bogus

subs.text: email servers aren't themselve inherently suspicious
they were fed republican fud and they went in whole hog
probably cost us our democracy, certainly made it a lot less likely we keep it
already a lot of people have died because of this mistake

body.text: what we can do about it is counteract the inaccurate news

subs.text: hold bootcamps for journalists when a technology becomes wrapped up in a major story
at least some of the journalists will have the correct picture.
go for journalists who are thorough, thoughtful and try to tell an accurate story
not going to name them but they are out there

body.text: we used to have a pretty vibrant journalism around tech

subs.text: weeklies and monthlies, for insiders and power users.
if you read them you'd be up on the latest developments
this doesn't seem to exist anymore. it's a shame, because in the 80s when we had such excellent coverage, tech might have had a few million users
now it's half the population of earth
so much more important that we stay up on this
if we're to have that reporters will have to develop deep knowledge of specific segments
not likely publishers will pay you to do this, you'd have to do it probably because you care about the world and don't want to see the mistakes of the past repeated

body.text: and for crying out loud learn how to write a bug report

subs.text: help developers create new user experiences
we need to have confidence that if we screw up our users will help us unscrew it quickly
we don't have the resources we used to have, just like journalism
and at the same time we seem to have lost the power users, people who loved the potential of tech so much that they wanted to help make it work.
if we don't have that kind of help, we can't push forward
it really is that simple
